column1: He shall, sir, an't please him. There's a letter for;"unedited";"William Shakespeare";"Hamlet";"Shakespeare
The wind sits in the shoulder of your sail
And you are stayed for. There
And these few precepts in thy memory
Look thou character. Give thy thoughts no tongue
Nor any unproportioned thought his act.
Be thou familiar
Those friends thou hast
Grapple them unto thy soul with hoops of steel
But do not dull thy palm with entertainment
Of each new-hatched
Of entrance to a quarrel
Bear 't that th' opposèd may beware of thee.
Give every man thy ear
Take each man's censure
Costly thy habit as thy purse can buy
But not expressed in fancy (rich
For the apparel oft proclaims the man
And they in France of the best rank and station
Are of a most select and generous chief in that.
Neither a borrower nor a lender be
For loan oft loses both itself and friend
And borrowing dulls the edge of husbandry.
This above all: to thine own self be true
And it must follow
Thou canst not then be false to any man.
Farewell. My blessing season this in thee.

column1: Clear consciences
That did us worthy comfort
Grief and disgrace invade us; and for all

[La Fin:] What! Did your highness hear?

And profit in experience of the slaveries

Of jealous state

The God of Eloquence his flowing speech
The feminine Deities strewed all their bounties
And beauty on his face: that eye was Juno's

As in a sacred Synod.";"";"#009010 Children of the Queen's Revels / #008006 Whitefriars

Like an impossibility

column1: To die fell tyrant.

Thou hast no power.

Prepar'd for such to howl in
The power of Princes
Tremble to think how terrible the dream is
After this sleep of death.

It may bring terror
What 'tis to die

column1: To wanton with the sun

She woos the gentle air
To hide her guilty front with innocent snow;

Pollute with sinful blame
The saintly veil of maiden white to throw;

Should look so near upon her foul deformities.";"Reference suggested in A Milton Encyclopedia

column1: Are like thin Chrystal glasses
Blown into excellent form
Cracked or quite broken: say I should consent
To your desires
You would repent the fact
Yourself surrounded in a mist of cares
View bashful Virgins point at you
Some hateful prodigy; hear matrons cry
There goes the lustful thief
The spoil of innocent Virgins
That has a hundred eyes to let lust in at
As many tongues to give his wild thoughts utterance. ";"First performance between 1634 and 1639.";"#009001 King's Men / #008001 The Globe

column1: And wrapt itself i'th' terrors of the night
I'll meet thee at Philippi

With such a voyce
As put the trembling Ghost to sudden flight
It vanisht as a Tapers light
Goes out when Spirits appear in sight.
One would have thought t'had heard <span class=""quote"">the morning crow
Or seen her well-appointed Star
Come marching up the Eastern Hill afar.
Nor durst it <span class=""quote"">in Philippi's field appear
But unseen attaqu'ed thee there.
Had it presum'ed in any shape thee to oppose
Thou wouldst have foro'ed it back upon thy foes:
Or slain't like Cæsar

column1: 'Cause he's like Esop's bat
For fools to poetry have no pretence
And common wit supposes common sense;
Not quite so low as fool
He hangs between them both
His morals
He keeps from arrant knave with much ado.
But vanity and lying so prevail
That one grain more of each would turn the scale;
He would be more a villain had he time
But he's so wholly taken up with rhyme
That he mistakes his talent; all his care
